summary.seg: Comprising several parts of separate production, each written in cursive scripts by late medieval hands, and assembled into a composite volume of complex structure by an early modern collector, this manuscript yields its information only to the most persistent researchers. When M.R. James came to describe the manuscript in 1902, he spent two pages of his catalogue listing the contents increasingly briefly, defeated perhaps by its complexities and its 'many hands, none very good', and ultimately dismissed the entire final section as 'receipts and miscellaneous notes, save at the end in a hand like that of Dr See [sic, for 'Dee']' (ff. 238-302). The Librarian of Trinity College, W.W. Greg, had similar difficulties, describing ff. 1-82 as simply 'a rough collection of tracts, verses, and receipts, of a medical character and rather confused', written 'mostly in a good plain hand'.

As James and Greg observed, Trinity College MS O.1.13 is devoted mainly to medical recipes and treatments, but, because of the nature of its production and the challenge its contents present, it has not received the level of scholarly attention that other manuscripts have attracted. This is partly due to persistent aesthetic biases, which Elaine Treharne detected in manuscript studies. Scientific and medical manuscripts are not usually known for their visual appeal, in terms either of illumination or of script. In consequence, they are generally described in negative terms, catalogued haphazardly, and edited infrequently. A further obstacle is that many are at once composite volumes and miscellanies. Composites comprise two or often more parts of different origins and dates of production, which may have been assembled in stages by different owners, and potentially long after the individual parts had been made. The reasons for their assembly are not always apparent, and therefore it can be difficult to capture effectively the spirit or purpose of the volume as a whole. The miscellaneous contents - of the individual parts, and of the whole - are in turn difficult to navigate. As Arthur Bahr observed, a miscellany is 'a complex assemblage of textual parts that does not obligingly present readers with a clear program or straightforward purpose'. This certainly rings true for scientific and medical texts, and for MS O.1.13 specifically: it does not stand out visually, it is a materially complex assemblage of at least ten parts, and its miscellaneous contents resist easy identification and classification.

There is, however, much to appreciate about this manuscript: a veritable treasure trove of largely unedited texts, each awaiting the attention of researchers. There are more than 600 pages crammed full of medical, culinary and alchemical recipes, and medical, herbal, horticultural and uroscopic treatises, and some miscellaneous writings as well. The recipe collections reveal the captivating realm of medieval medicine, and the intriguing aetiology of diseases: tooth decay described as being caused by worms, and the need for a remedy 'ffor any qwyke thynge that is cropyn into a mannys ere' (f. 70r). These texts feature a blend of human and veterinary medicine; of diagnostic, preventative and curative medicine; of recipes, charms, prognostication and divination; of remedies for both physical and spiritual, natural and supernatural complaints. The medical recipes in particular utilise an array of powders, syrups, pastes, treacles, baths, herbs, potions, salves, waters, poultices, purgations, plasters, ointments, juices, oils, prayers and incantations to treat pains, aches, fevers, fractures, stones, worms, wounds, coughs, palsies, swellings, fluxes, sores, incontinence, dropsy, gout, bleeding, baldness, insomnia, speechlessness, epilepsy, pestilence and necrosis, among many others.

The new description of the manuscript's contents, presented here by Clarck Drieshen, is so comprehensive that it marks a significant improvement on early descriptions such as M.R. James's, and even upon more recent, outstanding work such as by Linne Mooney for the Index of Middle English Prose. The textual units are identified in detail and in collections of short texts (such as the recipe collections) stand-out items have been described separately, especially those that appear incongruous in the immediate context. Thus, many of the charms and magical items in the medical recipe collections have been identified, to which may be added two strange remedies in the recipe collection on ff. 145r-154v. This collection is a series of short recipes on a variety of common complaints, but on f. 151c recto matters take a sinister turn. Among the recipes on this page, one is 'for a blaste of a wykked spyryt', which the recipe asserts manifests as a physical swelling in the face, and the next recipe is 'ffor the fyr of hell', which is a type of skin inflammation sometimes identified as erysipelas. What these two recipes have in common with charms and magical recipes is that they connect the natural and supernatural realms. Charms and magical recipes often remedy complaints with a natural aetiology by supernatural means, whereas the two recipes on f. 151c recto seem to remedy complaints with a supernatural aetiology by natural means. Presuming supernatural causes or prescribing supernatural cures stands out to us, because the supernatural is now not usually associated with medicine. Yet in medieval medical contexts, the natural and the supernatural were not categorically separate, although it is not uncommon for charms in medieval recipe collections to have been censored by later readers, in particular by religious reformers of the 16th century.

Many of the texts in MS O.1.13 circulated widely in the late medieval period, as the indices of Middle English writings by George Keiser and Linne Mooney demonstrate. The treatises on rosemary, some of the recipe collections, the poem on leechcraft, the lunaries, the poem on phlebotomy, the zodiacal texts and the horticultural treatises are attested in ca. 15-25 manuscripts, suggesting that the scribes of what was to become MS O.1.13 drew on an accepted body of scientific and medical learning. With so many text witnesses and scientific and medical manuscripts, it becomes possible to identify clusters of late medieval scientific and medical sources that were produced under similar conditions, as Linda Voigts did for the so-called 'Sloane Group' of manuscripts (see Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.77 for one such textual cluster from this group). Some parts of MS O.1.13 may likewise be connected to other manuscripts, through two potential clusters. The first consists of a poem on phlebotomy or bloodletting, days of the moon good or not good for bloodletting, thirty-two perilous days and prognostications for weather based on the appearance of the moon and sky (ff. 20r-21r). London, British Library, Sloane MS 963, ff. 71r-73v, has an identical cluster, in the same order, in the same words, in the same script and in a contemporary hand. A connection between MS O.1.13 and Sloane MS 963 is further corroborated by a second cluster, consisting of a tract on the four humours and the method for interpreting dreams using a psalter (f. 23r). Humoral lore and dream divination is not exactly an obvious pairing of texts, yet an identical cluster of texts occurs twice in Sloane MS 963, ff. 13r-13v and 55r-55v. This particular version of the method for interpreting dreams occurs only in the first part of MS O.1.13 and Sloane MS 963, which makes a connection between the two manuscripts even more likely.

Senior lecturer, Radboud Institute for Culture and History
Radboud University

supportDesc.support: A composite manuscript of (at least) ten separate codicological units consisting of paper leaves.

extent.seg: ii + 1 + 78 (= Part 1) | 66 (= Part 2) | 14 (= Part 3) | 12 (= Part 4) | 8 (= Part 5) | 56 (= Part 6) | 17 (= Part 7) | 49 (= Part 8) | 8 (= Part 9) | 11 (= Part 10) + ii leaves.

foliation.p: 16th- or 17th-century foliation supplemented and corrected by a modern hand:

note.p: Numbering in dark ink in the upper left-hand or right-hand corners or centres of the upper margins of the rectos with corrections and additions in pencil.

This foliation sequence is followed throughout this catalogue record. For reference purposes, unfoliated early modern and modern flyleaves have been allocated, respectively, Roman numerals and letters. These have been placed between square brackets in order to indicate that they are supplements to the foliation found in the volume itself.

Folios [a]-[b], and [c]-[d] are modern blank paper endleaves at the beginning and end of the manuscript; a strip of paper ([notes]) is kept in a 'folder' attached to f. [a] recto; f. [i] is a torn flyleaf at the beginning of the manuscript that has been repaired with early modern paper; f. [43a] is a blank stub [not photographed]; the lower part of f. 103 has been torn off; f. 104 is a torn leaf; f. 222a is a torn leaf; f. [ii] is an early modern leaf (perhaps a flyleaf) at the end of the manuscript.
Folios 15-19 are missing; the number '207' has been skipped in the foliation sequence.

foliation.note: Numbering in dark ink in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos. Crossed out. The foliator has added a note about the foliation in the left corner of the upper margins of f. 145: Continent in hoc libro fol. 26.
This foliation sequence is ignored in this catalogue record.
Numbering in dark ink in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos, continuing the foliation sequence on ff. 145-165. Often crossed out.
This foliation sequence is ignored in this catalogue record.
Numbering in dark ink in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos. Often crossed out.
This foliation sequence is ignored in this catalogue record.
Numbering in dark ink in the upper outer corners of the rectos and versos.
This pagination sequence is ignored in this catalogue record.
Numbering in dark ink in the upper outer corners of the rectos and versos.
This pagination sequence is ignored in this catalogue record.

collation.p: Due to the complexity of this manuscript, this collation is provisional and should be followed with caution. For some sections, it has not been possible to propose a plausible collation.

p.formula: 16-2 (1st-2nd missing) 26-1 or 4+1 (one missing in the quire's second half or one added to the quire's first half) 36-1 or 4+1 (one missing from the quire's second half or one added to the quire's first half) 42+1 (1st added) 5five (2nd is misbound in Quire 6) 6four (2 is misbound and belongs to Quire 5) 710-1 (6th missing) 810-1 or 8+1 (one missing from the quire's second half or one added to the quire's first half) 912-1 or 10+1 (one missing from the quire's first half or one added to the quire's second half) 10-1110 | 12?8 [collation not established for ff. 91-108] 13-1412 1510 16five | 172 18-196 | [? single leaf] 2010 [single leaf] | 218 | 22-238 2412 258 268-1 (7th missing) 274 288 | [?single leaf] 296 3010 | 31sixteen 328-1 (6th missing) | 338 | 3410 [? single leaf]

note.p: NB: This catalogue record deviates from the collation provided by M.R. James (1902): whereas James identifies eight parts, this record identifies ten parts: it considers James's Part III to consist of two separate parts (Part 3 and Part 4) and James's parts VII and VIII (James does not specify separate folio ranges) to consist of three parts (Parts 8, 9, and 10). This record also suggests that Part 8 (ff. 238-285) may consist of a few codicolocal units but since the collation for this part has not been established, it is not possible to confirm this.
Folio [i] recto has a paper 'folder' for a strip of ?17th-century paper (measuring 145 x 85mm). This strip contains calculations and notes about books with classmark references.
Folio [a] recto features a 17th-century table of contents for the entire manuscript, highlighting names that feature in different parts: Nathaniel Chierlo, Dr Stevens water, and Thomas Bradley.

binding.p: (?) 18th- or 19th-century brown leather over pasteboards with blind-tooled triple-line frames around the edges; a curved spine featuring a dark brown leather label with a gold-tooled frame and the gold-stamped inscription: RECIPES [et]c. and three paper pastedowns each with one the alpha-numerical elements of the manuscript's current classmark: O, 1, 13.

provenance.p: One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635/6-1702, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge.

One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father. Inscribed his name (Rogerus [G]) in the upper margin of f. 145r [see Provenance of Part 3].

acquisition.p: Donated to Trinity College by Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its classmark are printed on three paper tabs on the damaged spine: O, 1, 13. The classmark O.1.13 inscribed in pencil on the inside of the front cover. The old classmark C.65. inscribed in brown ink on f. [a] recto (according to M.R. James (1902), this manuscript is no. 197 in another old classmark system but this number is not found in the manuscript). The College's ex libris is printed on a paper pastedown on f. [a] verso (featuring its coat of arms and name: Collegium S.S. et Indiviudae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigiensi).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 2 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

msItem.title: Charms to cure epilepsy in adults and children
msItem.rubric: 51v ffor Ã¾e fallynge yuel
msItem.note: Describes the creation of an amulet: the charm text is written on parchment in the sufferer's own blood, and invokes the names of the Three Magi. Once the amulet has been written, gold, myrrh and frankincense should be put in and the amulet closed up and hung around the sufferer's neck. The patient should be blessed, and when he rises in the morning he should say three Pater Nosters and three Ave Marias, and every day for a month drink three roots of peony with stale ale. Further instructions describe a cure if the sufferer is a child: that the names of the Magi should be written in the child's blood in a 'masere' (i.e. a drinking bowl) and washed with either ale or milk, and the mixture given to the child to drink.

provenance.p: Richard Wistowe [Wystowe] (fl. 16th century) Wistowe [Wystowe], Richard, fl. 16th century: his (previously unnoticed) ownerhip inscription in a late 15th- or 16th-century hand on f. 82v: Ryche wystowe oeth this booke. He probably is Richard Wistowe, barber-surgeon of London and keeper of Leadenhall market from 1562, who served in the household of Sir Nicholas Bacon (1510â1579) and was still alive in the mid-1580s when he received an annual fee as recorded in the Chamberlain's Account of 1584-5. On Wistowe, see Ian W. Archer, 'Patronage and Clientage in Elizabethan London', Patronages et Clientelismes 1550-1750 (France, Angleterre, Espagne, Italie), ed. by Charles Giry-Deloison and Roger Mettam (Lille: l'Institut de recherches historiques du Septentrion, 2018), pp. 137-148.

msItem.title: Collection of medical and alchemical recipes

note.p: Folios 83r-119r predominantly contain features recipes in Latin and French with a few recipes in Italian (e.g. ff. 117r-117v). From f. 119v onwards, there are only recipes in Italian.

The collection includes various references to France and Italy. One recipe on f. 132r is entitled: Olio di San. Bernardino. Various recipes are attributed to specific (?) French and Italian medical practitioners:
M. Malkean (f. 83r)
Operatio secundum domini Chamberlanti de â¾ (f. 85r) [unidentified]
Mr Augustin (f. 84v) [unidentified]
Dom. Chamb. (f. 84v) [unidentified]
M. Cham. (f. 87r) [unidentified]
J.b. [3x] (ff. 92r, 93v) [unidentified]
M. de la Baulm and M. Bourd [2x] (f. 93v) [unidentified]
M. de Beaulieu, M. Li., De Burd. (f. 94r) [unidentified]
Dominus de Burdalow (f. 84v) [unidentified]
Receypt de madame de Nemours (f. 94v) [unidentified]
M. de la Pierre [4x] (ff. 95r-95v) [unidentified]
Chamberlant (f. 95v) [unidentified]
Mr Bourdalou (f. 96v) [unidentified]
Mr Rodamont (f. 97r [unidentified]
Mr Claud de Auig. (f. 98v) [unidentified]
M. Galli (f. 113r) [unidentified]
Prouato - Nathaniele Chierlo (f. 122v) [unidentified]

The collection also features a recipe for Weapon Salve on (ff. 88r-88v) that is attributed to Paracelsus (1493â1541): Vnguentum ad vulnera Parakel[sis]. Further references to Paracelsus occur in the collection's alchemical recipe (e.g. see f. 111v-112r [Paral. in Chirurgia Magna, referring to his Grosse Wundarznei of 1536], and f. 113v [Paracelsus in libro Hospitarum]).

Many recipes have been crossed out. On f. 84r, a few words of the recipe's title and instructions have been written in a cypher. Words have been crossed out and replaced with the same cypher on ff. 120v and 121r.

Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge: inscribed his name Rogerus [G] in a 17th- or 18th-century hand in the upper margin of f. 145r. The location of his signature may suggest that this part was initially kept separately and joined to the rest of manuscript by Roger Gale.

msItem.title: Note on a bill in parliament
msItem.textLang: Middle English with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 204v Note in anno secundo regis Henrici vti
msItem.incipit: 204v There was a bill of supplicacioun putt into the parliament house then theffecte wherof was thatt the temporall landes douetly gyven and disordynatly spent by religious and other spirituall persons myght suffyce to mayntene yerely to the honour of the kynge and defence of the realme xv. erles xvC knyghtes vjMl ijC esquiers C of almeshuses And xxM li yerely to the kinges coffers before the mayntenaunce provisions and valewes of yerely pensions lymyted vnto dyuers sufficient housez of regioun whiche was then thought necessari to stand and to mayteyne
msItem.note: Full transcription. According to Mooney (1995), the dating given in the heading is incorrect; the bill would concern a request to seize alien priories that dates to the second year of the reign of Henry IV (1402); see Mooney (1995), p. 72.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for medicines, cooking, ink and pigments

note.p:
The collection includes a few recipes with attributions to medical practitioners:
Mr Rancklins [or Raucklius] medicine of Curbige by witnye for that cured of my wifes brest April 26. 1609 (f. 238v) [unidentified]
Mr Cogans water for a canker or to wash any wounde to clense it or remoue the deade flesh (f. 240r) [perhaps referring to Thomas Cogan, physician of Manchester, who published The Haven of Health in 1584 or 1586 (subsequent editions in 1589, 1596, 1605, 1636); see George Eric Simpson, 'The Haven of Health', The Scientific Monthly, 10:1 (1920), 26-37 (pp. 26-27)]

Aside from medical recipes, the the collection contains a few culinary recipes: To make surger plate, To make all kind of concertes of march[e]pane, To presarue apricots or pere [or] plumbes, to take [...] the molthe out of rose water.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes for purgation
msItem.rubric: 243r Dr Andrews Purgation

note.p: The collection contains a charm for staunching nosebleeds (f. 244v) with different instructions for male and female patient: ffor a man Ã¾at bleedeth at the nose. Take and write in his forhead this word (berenix), and if it be a woman this word berenixa +.
Another hand has added a recipe to To stap vrine and pissing in bed in which the first instance of the word patient has been crossed out and women has been supplied above.

msItem.title: Poem (Octet) on death [unfinished]
msItem.rubric: 248r A table of good Counsell
msItem.incipit: 248r Let men apply to serve and please but pleasing rather set before / ffor service sometymes, but pleasing often getteth more. / Time past remember while wee may and thinges foresee which will ensue / So shall wee seldome rane astray and haue as seldome cause to rue / In fickle life no trust repose, whose state enioyes noe certantye / ffor in each place the bodye goes, death as a
msItem.note: Full transcription. Unfinished version of the complete poem on f. 249r. This poem was printed together with A Salue for a sick soule (see the item after the next one) on a broadside sheet which Valentine Sims registered for publication in 1598. In 1599 he transferred his rights to John Brown. See Hyder E. Rollins, Old English Ballads, 1553-1625 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1920), p. 405.

msItem.title: Poem (Octet) on death [complete]
msItem.incipit: 249r Let men apply to serve and please, but pleasing rather set before / ffor service sometymes gets some case, but pleasing often getteth more / Time past remember while wee may and thinges foresee which will ensue / Soe shall wee seldome run astray . and haue as seldome cause to rue / In fickle life noe trust repose whose state enioyes noe certayntye / ffor in ach place the bodye goes, death as a shaddow followes thee / Remember death but feare him not, though death to life be mortall foe / ffor by mans death doth fall his lot, a lasting ioy or endles woe.
msItem.note: Full transcription. Finished version of the incomplete poem on f. 248r. This poem was printed together with A Salue for a sick soule (see next item) on a broadside sheet which Valentine Sims registered for publication in 1598. In 1599 he transferred his rights to John Brown. See Hyder E. Rollins, Old English Ballads, 1553-1625 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1920), p. 405.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for medicines, cooking, ink and pigments

note.p: The collection contains a few recipes that have been attributed to medical practitioners: Mistris Clares medicine for an ould sore (f. 284r) [unidentified]; and a recipe ffor a red pumpled scurvie and itching face that is said to have been proved by Mr Doyly (f. 284v) [unidentified].

Aside from medical recipes, the collection contains recipes for making inks and pinks: Inke of Lumbardy, To make verdigrece or verdit, To make gum Edrek, To write golde with mead, To counterfayt quielles and to make turpentine, To make white varnish, Colours in varnish, To make black varnish, To sublime marcury, To make a graving with the grave in Iron or steele. It also contains various culinary recipes: To claryfy hony, To make comfets, To make lossinges, To make white marmelad, To make whole sugar of Ã¾e poio, To conserve quinces, To make sucket of lettis cheries, To make suckit of quinces or wardens or pares, Syrrop of roses, To make greene ginger, To preserue Ã¾e drie figes, ffor my brother Carye, Synaman water.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 238-285: Jug.

list.item: The collation for ff. 258-285 has not been established.

p.seg: o ruling. Single columns. c 35-45 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by several late 16th- and/or 17th-century hands in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 274r-277v have been copied by a single scribe in a humanistic cursive script (probably the same hand that copied ff. 287r-292v).

decoNote.p: Drawings in brown ink of a hand (manicule) pointing at text and a human face in the lower margin of f. 271r.

provenance.p: Thomas Norton (fl. c. 1575-1650) Norton, Thomas, fl. c. 1575-1650: owned or accessed the manuscript. His name Thomas Norton written in a late 16th- or early 17th-century script in the lower margin of f. 251v. Perhaps the Thomas Norton who was licensed to practise medicine by the University of Cambridge in 1628 (see John H. Raach, 'English Medical Licensing in the Early Seventeenth Century', Journal of Biology and Medicine, 16:4 (1944), pp. 267-288 (p. 283 fn. 31)); or the Thomas Norton (d. 1669) - possibly the same as previous - who was appointed physician in extraordinary to King Charles II in 1668 (see Peter Elmer, Medicine in an Age of Revolution (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2023), p. 346).

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.13, ff. 285a, 286-292

msItem.title: Off-set of medieval text
msItem.note: Off-set of a page of medieval text (unidentified), written in a neat textualis script, that once sat opposite this page, probably as a flyleaf.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.rubric: 286r for a spraine or swelling about any horse eyther leggs or limmes

msItem.title: Name inscription
msItem.note: The name Emanuell in mirror writing.

msItem.title: Allegorical poem on the Seven Deadly Sins as members of a royal court
msItem.incipit: 286r Tiraunie his servaunt monie is his master / Pride is his page and gluttony his taster / Flatterie his attendaunt alwaies at his heele / Drunkenes his companion that [crossed out: made] caused him to reele / Anger his foole envie is his seate / ?Jealusie his God and luxury his meate / My tonge \nor pen/ can his imperfections tel[l] / Therefore my penne shall \in/ his dispraises ?d[well]
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the late 16th or early 17th century.

msItem.title: Oration on natural philosophy by a certain J. P. dated to 28 November 1586
msItem.rubric: 287r Oratio J. P. cum esset decimus pl[...]s 28 Nouembri 1586
msItem.note: The text contains quotations from Cicero, Hippocrates, Plato. In the lower margin of f. 292r is an inscription seemingly by the same hand (but using lighter ink) that copied the oration: Per me Thomam Bradley.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 285a-292: Jug.

p.seg: No ruling. Single columns. c. 30-45 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a single scribe in a humanistic cursive script (probably the same hand that copied ff. 274r-277v).

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

origin.p: Terminus ante quem non based on date of Oration on ff. 287r-288v.

provenance.p: Thomas Bradley (fl. 1580s-1590s) Bradley, Thomas, fl. 1580s-1590s: perhaps copied and owned this part of the manuscript. His name inscribed in a late 16th-century script in the lower margin of f. 292r: Per me Thomam Bradley. Unidentified.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.13, ff. 293-302, [ii]

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Folio 293r is blank except for a recipe's title: An spoera recte statuatur. The collection contains a few recipes that have been attributed to medical practitioners: a recipe Contra omnes dolores (f. 295r) is said to have been proved Per Sr Thomas Terril eques [unidentified]; a recipe To cause a man to speake Ã¾at hath lost his speech (f. 296v) is said to have been proved by John Mosly [unidentified].

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The first recipe is attributed to a King Henry (Ad sciaticam passionem . experimentum . Regis Hen[rici]), perhaps King Henry VIII who was associated with various medical recipes, a collection of which survives in London, British Library, Sloane MS 1047.

msItem.title: Index of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 298r A. Antimonij secret 297b
msItem.explicit: 302v Z. Zinzyber 280b
msItem.note: This index covers recipes in Parts 7, 8, and 9 and refers to the foliation sequence that can be found throughout the manuscript. Consequently, it must have been added at a point when all parts of the manuscript had been joined together, presumably in the 17th century.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 293-[302a]: Jug.

list.item: Folio [b] appears to be a single leaf.

p.seg: Ruled in ink (ff. 293r-297r) and hardpoint (ff. 298r-302v), frame only. Single columns (except for ff. 298r-302v which have two columns). c. 30-40 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 297r-297v are (largely) written by a single hand in a humanistic cursive script.
Folios 298r-302v are (largely) written by a single hand in a humanistic cursive script.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

provenance.p: John Dee (1527â1608) Dee, John, 1527â1608, mathematician, astrologer, and antiquary: perhaps copied and owned this part of the manuscript. As M.R. James (1902) notes, the script in this part resembles his handwriting. More specifically, the hand seems identical to that in part 4 of Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.9.39; Julian Roberts and Andrew G. Watson [John Dee's Library Catalogue (London: Bibliographical Society, 1990)] identify this hand as that of John Dee.
